Hi Paul.

Thanks again for the answers to my questions. A few responses are
inline below.

At Tue, 11 Dec 2007 17:58:57 -0800,
Paul Jack <pjack@...> wrote:
>
> > Is it possible to explain the rationale for leaving order.xml
> > files behind? I know that we have some investment in the format,
> > and though we can of course move forward it is not clear to me
> > from looking at the sheets.
>
> There were a number of reasons:
>
> 1. The XML wasn't well-defined for most modules, so the benefits of
> XML were mostly lost. Eg, it would be nice to have
>
> <FetchDNS>
> <accept-non-dns-resolves>false</accept-non-dns-resolves>
> <deciderules/>
> <digest-algorithm>SHA1</digest-algorithm>
> <digest-content>true</digest-content>
> <enabled>true</enabled>
> </FetchDNS>
>
> ...so that configuration sheets could be validated using standard
> XML tools. But that would also be a huge departure from the existing
> order.xml, would require more infrastructure, and would make it more
> difficult to support third-party modules.

While I agree that the order.xml format what a bit funny looking, I’ve
just spent a bit of time convincing myself that a pretty reasonable
schema could have been written to validate the order.xml format with
relax ng.

> 2. XML's nesting provides a good visual sense of structure for the
> old order.xml and for the new global sheet, but didn't work so well
> for override sheets, which typically contain only a few settings.
> We'd either have to nest many levels of empty tags to get to the
> actual overrides, or have two different XML formats for the global
> sheet and override sheets.

This makes a lot of sense.

> 3. The one-setting-per-line format plays well with command-line tools
> such as diff.

Also makes sense.

> 4. The one-setting-per-line format closely resembles the new JMX API
> for modifying sheets. In particular, code used for JMX transport of
> settings is re-used to read/write the sheet files.

Aha. This makes even more sense.

Thanks for your detailed answers. If I seem reluctant to leave behind
the order.xml format, it is not for a particular love of xml or the
order.xml format. It is simply that we have infrastructure deployed
that makes use of order.xml. Additionally, I have been developing an
HTTP interface for Heritrix which extends the order.xml format to
allow creating jobs, retrieving data, etc. from a running Heritrix
instance using HTTP (rather than JMX), and I am going to have to
determine how to rework this to work with the new settings format. I
had not realized until a few days ago that the new settings had
progressed so far and that order.xml files were to be left behind.

> […]
> The second one is not an empty string; it's saying "Create a new list
> that will only contain String values." To add an elements to the list
> you'd use:
>
> root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers:0=string, audio/*;
> q=0.2, audio/basic
> root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers:1=string, text/*, text/
> html, text/html;level=1

Ok, so a distinction is made between primitives and objects,
basically.

Since the order of the lines matters for maps, can you do something to
append to a list? For instance:

root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers:_=string, audio/*; q=0.2, audio/basic

Just a though, since I generally dislike hard coding the index of a
list.

> > Why is the config.txt file necessary?
>
> It bootstraps the settings system. Since the settings system itself
> uses a BDB, we needed a place to put the configuration for BDB.

Make sense, thanks.

> > Can one define any settings in it?
>
> No; the contents of config.txt are predefined. The valid properties
> are all listed in the file; anything not listed is simply ignored.

Ok. Thanks.

> > What is the difference between ‘primary, org.archive[...]’ and
> > ‘object, org.archive[...]’?
>
> Each class of object can have one "primary" object nominated in the
> global sheet. If a setting uses the "primary" tag then the object
> created is registered as the primary.
>
> Primary objects are automatically selected as the default value for
> most module settings. For instance, FetchHTTP has a server-cache
> setting for specifying the ServerCache to use with FetchHTTP. The
> default value for that setting is to use the "primary" ServerCache.
> In this way only one ServerCache instance needs to be specified in
> the sheet, and all the modules that need it just find it.

I had assumed (correctly, I think) that in the past the names of
certain objects determined their primary-ness (for instance, the
object named ‘scope’ was the scope used for the crawl). This seems to
make more sense than enforcing a particular name for the settings.

best,
Erik Hetzner
